awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Molecular and Biochemical Analysis of Proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Purdue University in West Lafayette, Indiana, will provide research training for eight students for ten weeks during the summers of 2018- 2020. The program provides advanced training in the analysis of protein function. It facilitates detailed understanding of experimental laboratory research, insights into protein biochemistry and appreciation for the broader context of research. Projects mentored by faculty in the Department of Biochemistry include analysis of enzyme mechanisms, post-translational protein modifications, proteomics, and protein-nucleic acid interactions studied in a wide range of biological contexts including cell cycle control, epigenetic gene regulation and plant development. A three-day orientation will introduce key concepts in protein biochemistry and experimental design. The remainder of the program will emphasize full-time research supplemented with weekly sessions on ethical conduct in research, professional communication and the graduate school application process. Students will present their results at a departmental symposium and a university-wide poster session. The program will recruit life science and chemistry undergraduates with at least four semesters of college who have an interest in research. Selection of participants will be based on academic performance, demonstrated interest in research, and the potential for outstanding research careers in the life sciences. 

It is anticipated that a total of 24 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program with additional emphasis on recruiting students from groups that are underrepresented in the life sciences. Students will learn how research is conducted, improve their scientific communication skills and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Additional assessments on student poster presentations will be performed. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths and will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by visiting http://www.ag.purdue.edu/biochem/Pages/REU.aspx, or by contacting the PI (Dr. James Forney at forney@purdue.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
This 10-week summer Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) provided scientific training for a total of 24 students over three summers on the Purdue University campus (the program was canceled in 2020 due to COVID-19). The intellectual theme was focused on the analysis of proteins. This class of molecules has a wide range of physical properties and often requires individualized approaches for their purification and study. Students received an intense introduction to protein analysis during the first three days that included presentations by graduate students, interpretation of data and practice reading scientific papers. During the remainder of the program each student worked on an independent research project mentored by a faculty member. The projects used biochemical and genetic techniques to investigate proteins with functions in virus replication, plant metabolism, gene regulation and enzyme mechanisms. In addition to research, the students attended professional development sessions that covered the ethical conduct of research, preparing applications to graduate school, the process of scientific publication, receiving feedback from mentors and scientific communication. Students met with employees from biotechnology companies and discussed career opportunities in industry. Scientific communication skills were developed with a written summary of the proposed project due within the first two weeks, a poster presentation, and a short oral presentation in the final week. Practice sessions for the posters and talks included feedback from faculty and senior graduate students and exposed students to the diverse approaches used to tackle questions of protein function.

Student surveys administered before and after the program showed that participants made significant gains in their knowledge and confidence to discuss biochemical research, design biochemical experiments, understand biochemical methods, design and present scientific posters and read the scientific literature. Six students presented their research at national meetings including the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (ASBMB), the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (ABRCMS) and the Society for Advancing Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) National Digital Conference. Two students were co-authors on peer-reviewed scientific publications in the field of biochemistry.

More than 70% of participating students were from small colleges or universities with limited research opportunities. Sixty three percent enrolled in graduate or professional school, 25% took jobs in biotechnology immediately after completing their bachelor?s degree and 12% are still completing their undergraduate degree or a postgraduate internship. In addition to the benefits provided to the student participants, the program provided training and mentoring opportunities for graduate students as they prepare for careers in education and industry.

Publications:

Dar MS, Mensah IK, He M, McGovern S, Sohal IS, Whitlock HC, Bippus NE, Ceminsky M, Emerson ML, Tan HJ, Hall MC, Gowher H. (2023) Dnmt3bas coordinates transcriptional induction and alternative exon inclusion to promote catalytically active Dnmt3b expression. Cell Rep. 42(6):112587.

Jauregui-Lozano J., McGovern SE, Bakhle KM, Hagins AC, Weake, VM. (2023) Establishing the contribution of active histone methylation marks to the aging transcriptional landscape of Drosophila photoreceptors. Sci Rep. 13(1):5105.

 


Last Modified: 06/22/2023
Modified by: James D Forney
